quests: Prophesied during the rebuilding of the Second Temple
Proclaimed messianic oracles of the coming king
Foretold the king riding on a donkey
Revealed the pierced one whom they would mourn
feats: Encouraged the rebuilding of the Second Temple
Prophesied the triumphal entry - king on a donkey
Foretold the shepherd struck and sheep scattered
Revealed the thirty pieces of silver prophecy
Prophesied the pierced one and mourning
name: Zechariah the Prophet | Jewish Heroes

attributes.context: Return from Babylonian exile, Second Temple period

triumphantEntry.hebrewText: גִּילִי מְאֹד בַּת־צִיּוֹן הָרִיעִי בַּת יְרוּשָׁלִָם הִנֵּה מַלְכֵּךְ יָבוֹא לָךְ צַדִּיק וְנוֹשָׁע הוּא עָנִי וְרֹכֵב עַל־חֲמוֹר וְעַל־עַיִר בֶּן־אֲתֹנוֹת
triumphantEntry.translation: Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion! Shout aloud, O daughter of Jerusalem! Behold, your king is coming to you; righteous and having salvation is he, humble and mounted on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.
significance: King coming in humility, not military might
Riding a donkey - sign of peace, not war horse

gospelFulfillment.event: Jesus' triumphal entry into Jerusalem on Palm Sunday

piercedOne.hebrewText: וְהִבִּיטוּ אֵלַי אֵת אֲשֶׁר־דָּקָרוּ וְסָפְדוּ עָלָיו כְּמִסְפֵּד עַל־הַיָּחִיד
piercedOne.translation: And I will pour out on the house of David and the inhabitants of Jerusalem a spirit of grace and pleas for mercy, so that, when they look on me, on him whom they have pierced, they shall mourn for him, as one mourns for an only child.
significance: Divine speaker ('look on me') who is pierced
Mourning as for an only son

newTestamentApplication.context: Every eye will see him, even those who pierced him

shepherdStruck.translation: Strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered
shepherdStruck.significance: Shepherd's death leads to scattering of flock

gospelFulfillment.context: Jesus quotes this the night of his arrest

thirtyPiecesOfSilver.translation: Then I said to them, 'If it seems good to you, give me my wages; but if not, keep them.' And they weighed out as my wages thirty pieces of silver... 'Throw it to the potter.'
significance: Thirty pieces of silver - price of a slave (Exodus 21:32)

gospelFulfillment.context: Judas' betrayal price and the potter's field

cleavedMountOlives.translation: On that day his feet shall stand on the Mount of Olives that lies before Jerusalem on the east, and the Mount of Olives shall be split in two from east to west.
cleavedMountOlives.eschatologicalSignificance: End-time appearance of the LORD on Mount of Olives

ascensionConnection.text: This Jesus, who was taken up from you into heaven, will come in the same way as you saw him go into heaven. Then they returned to Jerusalem from the mount called Olivet.

nightVisions.description: Eight apocalyptic visions received in one night (Zechariah 1-6)

branchProphecy.hebrewText: הִנֵּה־אִישׁ צֶמַח שְׁמוֹ וּמִתַּחְתָּיו יִצְמָח וּבָנָה אֶת־הֵיכַל יְהוָה
branchProphecy.translation: Behold, the man whose name is the Branch: for he shall branch out from his place, and he shall build the temple of the LORD... and shall bear royal honor, and shall sit and rule on his throne. And there shall be a priest on his throne.
branchProphecy.significance: The Branch unites priestly and kingly offices - priest-king
branchProphecy.connectionToIsaiah11: Netzer/Tsemach - Branch imagery links Isaiah and Zechariah

philipPerspective.mosesAndProphets: Zechariah's prophecies are fulfilled in Jesus' final week
philipPerspective.propheticWitness: Zechariah's precision proves divine inspiration of prophecy

description: Zechariah (Zekharyah) is the prophet of the lowly king, whose messianic prophecies are fulfilled with remarkable precision in Jesus' passion week. His oracle of the king riding on a donkey (Zechariah 9:9) was fulfilled on Palm Sunday, while his prophecies of the thirty pieces of silver, the struck shepherd, and the pierced one frame the crucifixion narrative. His apocalyptic visions and Branch prophecy connect to other messianic texts.

metadata.focus: Passion week prophecies and Philip's perspective
